attributes.title: Cooperation under uncertainty in natural resource management

q1.value: Cooperation under uncertainty in natural resource management

q2.value: Andries Richter | Esther Schuch | Tum Nhim

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In Cambodia, governance of natural resources, such as water and fish resources remains a challenge due to increasing scarcity and low cooperation among famers in sharing the resources and enforcing rules and norms that prescribe resource use. The overall aim of this project is to analyze how social norms of cooperation among farmers and fishers in Cambodia can be fostered and preserved in times of increased scarcity. Framed field experiments will be conducted in 21 villages in the Kampong Chhnang river basin to understand how uncertainty and the institutional setting affect levels of cooperation among farmers in response to increasing water scarcity. In Cambodia, water and fisheries governance relies largely on informal agreements of community groups, organized per village. The agreements are non-binding, but stimulate social norms of cooperation, such as sharing water between farmers. While some groups are successful, others face an overuse of resources which can lead to conflicts between stakeholders. Climate change is expected to increase stress on the availability of fish and water, but an open question is to which degree. The uncertainty related to the resource abundance combined with a weak institutional setting is the background upon which we built our research on cooperation.

q16.value: We focus upon three main research questions. 1) How does prior exposure to scarcity and demographic variables affect cooperation and how does this interact with risk tolerance? 2) How does the level of cooperation depend on the framing of an environmental good (providing a public good vs. avoiding a public bad) 3) Are people willing to contribute parts of their revenues for a monitoring system to foster cooperation?

q17.value: We use economic experiments (see pre-analysis plan) combined with a survey to answer these questions. Question 1 will be addressed by a risk elicitation game (Task 1), a standard public goods game (Task 2) and a public goods game with strategy elicitation (Task 3). Question 2 will be addressed by a public goods threshold game with a between subject design Task 4). Treatment one frames the game as a public good and treatment two as a public bad. Question 3 will be assessed by Tasks 5 & 6, which are based on standard public goods games. In both task the subjects are allowed to vote for their preferred institutional setting. In task 5, the choice is between a tax system which ensures a minimum contribution to the public good or a public goods setting which is purely voluntary. In task 6, the participants can vote for a costly monitoring system that discourages free-riding form the public good.

attributes.title: The Effects of Nonconforming Dress Style in Personnel Selection Contexts:  Do Applicants’ Qualifications Matter?

summary.value: This document includes the hypotheses and a description of the methods of a study on the effects of nonconforming dress style in selection contexts

registration_responses.summary: This document includes the hypotheses and a description of the methods of a study on the effects of nonconforming dress style in selection contexts

attributes.title: Alpha power modulation by tACS : systematic Review
attributes.description: This registration is for an ongoing systematic review on transcranial alternating current stimulation (tACS) for alpha activity modulation. Preliminary searchers, study selection process formal screening of search results against eligibility criteria, data extraction and risk of bias (quality assessment) have been completed. Data analysis is remains to be pursued. The attached file contains a sample of research strategy on medline.

summary.value: This registration is for an ongoing systematic review on transcranial alternating current stimulation (tACS) for alpha activity modulation. data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Are the gender differences found in friendships due to perceived/actual intimacy?

other.value: Any anonymous data collected in this study may later be used by the researcher (Vickie Curtis) or supervisor (Thomas Pollet) for additional research. The analyses conducted by the supervisor might be different and could be more complex. However, they'll also examine gender differences in emotional closeness.

sample.value: The study will collect data until 100 participants have completed the questionnaire, or until 20th February 2020 (whichever comes first).

analyses.value: The analysis used for this study will be mediation analysis, to analyse the effects of intimacy (the mediator variable) on the relationship between gender differences (the independent variable) and emotional closeness (the dependent variable) in friendships.

outliers.value: Any participants who did not complete the questionnaire will have their data removed, as this is the participant withdrawing from the study.

dependent.value: The dependent variable in this study is the emotional closeness on a 0-10 scale. The proposed mediator is intimacy in friendship, which is measured in the answers provided to the intimacy questions from the McGills Friendship Questionnaire. It will also be treated as a dependent variable to establish whether women are more intimate with their friends.

conditions.value: There will be no conditions in this research, this study uses a non-experimental correlational design.

hypothesis.value: The hypothesis proposed for this study is that females will be more intimate with their same-gender friends in comparison to males same-gender friends due to the 'fuller' relationships/friendships females appear to have based in previous literature (based on intimacy). This will be examined via the answers provided to the 5 intimacy questions from McGills Friendship Questionnaire that are asked about each friend the participant has listed.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will collect data from 40 participants or until April 30, 2020 (whichever comes first).

analyses.value:
Trials with RT<100ms or RT>2000ms will be excluded.
Only RT for correct trials will be included in the analysis.  
RT will be log transformed to approach a normal distribution. 

One sample t-tests will be employed to compare valid and invalid condition on accuracy and RT.
We will compute a difference RT score between the valid and the invalid condition. We will run a multiple regression with the score from the questionnaires as predictors and the difference RT score as dependent variable.

outliers.value: All participants who do not have a smartphone and those who have an accuracy < 75% will be excluded from further analyses.

dependent.value:
The main task is inspired by the dot-probe procedure. Briefly, on each trial two icons of smartphone applications are presented for 100 ms, on the left and on the right of a continuously visible central fixation cross. The icons are either a social networks icon (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat and WhatsApp) or a smartphone application (Calculator, Google Maps, Weather, Internet Explorer and Camera). Immediately after the icons disappear, a target, consisting of a triangle pointing upward or downward, is presented in the location of one of the icons. On valid trials, the target appears in the same location of the social network icon, on invalid trials, the target appears at the location previously occupied by the control icon. A total of 200 trials (100 valid and 100 invalid) are presented. Participants are instructed to indicate the direction of the target as fast as possible using the corresponding keyboard arrow. At the end of the task, participants are asked to estimate for each icon, on a 10-points Likert scale, the familiarity, the frequency of usage, and their preference.  

Questionnaires:
-	State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-YB; Spielberger, 1983): self-assessment questionnaire about trait of anxiety composed by 20 items. The participant checks the box between “always”, “often”, “sometimes” or “hardly ever”. 
-	Fear of Missing Out (Przybylski, Murayama, DeHaan, & Gladwell, 2013): self-assessment questionnaire about fear of missing out that is characterized by the desire to stay continually connected with what others are doing. This questionnaire is composed of 10 items on a five-point Likert-type scale: 1 = ‘‘Not at all true of me’’, 2 = ‘‘Slightly true of me’’, 3 = ‘‘Moderately true of me’’, 4 = ‘‘Very true of me’’, and 5 = ‘‘Extremely true of me’’. Individual scores can be computed by averaging responses to all ten items and forms a reliable composite measure (α = .87 to .90). 
-	The Smartphone Usage Questionnaire (Marty-Dugas, Ralph, Oakman, & Smilek, 2018)): it is composed by 20 items on a 7-points scale ranging from 1 (Never) to 7 (All the time), the higher score is 140. The questionnaire is composed by two subscales: the Smartphone Use Questionnaire General (SUQ-G), and the Smartphone Use Questionnaire Absent-Minded (SUQ-A). The former allows measuring the use of the smartphone in terms of frequency (e.g., send and receive text messages, use social media). The latter assess the frequency with which individuals are engaged with their phones absent-mindedly. 
-	Social Networking Activity Intensity Scale (Li, Lau, Mo, Su, Wu, Tang, & Qin, 2016): this questionnaire gathers the common functions and activities of online social networking use. It is composed of 14 items on a 5-points Likert-scale from 0 = “never” to 4= “always”, the higher score is 56.
-	Emotional connection to social networking (Ellison, Steinfield, & Lampe, 2007): it is a measure of Facebook usage, but we generalize to all the social networks. The questionnaire specifies how the participant is emotionally connected to social networks and the extent to which social networks are integrated into her daily activities. It is composed of 6 assertions rated from 1= “strongly disagree” to 5= “strongly agree”, so the higher score is 30.

References

Ellison, N. B., Steinfield, C., & Lampe, C. (2007). The benefits of Facebook “friends:” Social capital and college students’ use of online social network sites. Journal of computer-mediated communication, 12(4), 1143-1168.
Li, J., Lau, J. T., Mo, P. K., Su, X., Wu, A. M., Tang, J., & Qin, Z. (2016). Validation of the Social Networking Activity Intensity Scale among junior middle school students in China. PloS one, 11(10).
Marty-Dugas, J., Ralph, B. C., Oakman, J. M., & Smilek, D. (2018). The relation between smartphone use and everyday inattention. Psychology of Consciousness: Theory, Research, and Practice, 5(1), 46.
Przybylski, A. K., Murayama, K., DeHaan, C. R., & Gladwell, V. (2013). Motivational, emotional, and behavioral correlates of fear of missing out. Computers in Human Behavior, 29, 1814-1848.
Spielberger, C. D. (1983) State-trait anxiety inventory for adults (STAI-AD).

The dependent variables for the study are :
-	Accuracy (% of correct responses),
-	Reaction time (ms),
-	Subjective report (1-10): familiarity, frequency of usage, and preference.
-	Questionnaires scores (STAI-YB, Fear of Missing Out, The Smartphone Usage Questionnaire, Social Networking Activity Intensity Scale, Emotional connection to social networking).

hypothesis.value:
Attention can be oriented in a top-down or a bottom-up fashion (Corbetta and al., 2002). Different stimuli have been shown to automatically capture attentional resources. Classically these stimuli encompass emotional laden stimuli (Fabio, 2019; Sutton and Lutz, 2018; Vuilleumier, 2005). In particular, phylogenetic relevant stimuli (e.g., threating stimuli), due to their survival value, have been reported to capture attention (Öhman and al., 2001). Nevertheless, Brosch and al. (2005) reported that also ontogenetic threating stimuli (e.g. weapons) can capture attention. While most of the studies focused on negative stimuli, other work showed that positive phylogenetic relevant stimuli (e.g. baby faces; Brosch and al., 2007) or neutral stimuli associated with a reward (Watson and al., 2019) can automatically capture attention.  
With the spreading of smartphone usage, socials networks are ever-present in our daily life. Some studies reported that social networks usage can activate the brain reward system (Meshi et al., 2015). Thus, it is possible that social networks have acquired, via their rewarding power, the ability to capture attention. Moreover, this effect could be modulated by the usage behavior and the affective commitment toward social networks.
The main hypothesis of the study is that social media icons would automatically capture attention compared to a control condition. A corollary hypothesis is that attentional facilitation would correlate with social media usage and some affective measures (anxiety, fear of missing out).

References

Brosch, T., & Sharma, D. (2005). The role of fear-relevant stimuli in visual search: a comparison of phylogenetic and ontogenetic stimuli. Emotion, 5(3), 360. 
Brosch, T., Sander, D., & Scherer, K. R. (2007). That baby caught my eye... Attention capture by infant faces. Emotion, 7(3), 685–689. 
Corbetta, M., & Shulman, G. L. (2002). Control of goal-directed and stimulus-driven attention in the brain. Nature reviews neuroscience, 3(3), 201.
Fabio, R. A., & Caprì, T. (2019). Automatic and controlled attentional capture by threatening stimuli. Heliyon, 5(5), e01752.
Meshi, D., Tamir, D. I., & Heekeren, H. R. (2015). The emerging neuroscience of social media. Trends in cognitive sciences, 19(12), 771-782.
Öhman, A., Flykt, A., & Esteves, F. (2001). Emotion drives attention: detecting the snake in the grass. Journal of experimental psychology: general, 130(3), 466.
Sutton, T. M., & Lutz, C. (2019). Attentional capture for emotional words and images: The importance of valence and arousal. Canadian Journal of Experimental Psychology/Revue canadienne de psychologie expérimentale, 73(1), 47.
Vuilleumier, P. (2005). How brains beware: neural mechanisms of emotional attention. Trends in cognitive sciences, 9(12), 585-594.
Watson, P., Pearson, D., Most, S. B., Theeuwes, J., Wiers, R. W., & Le Pelley, M. E. (2019). Attentional capture by Pavlovian reward-signalling distractors in visual search persists when rewards are removed. PloS one, 14(12).

Classically these stimuli encompass emotional laden stimuli (Fabio, 2019; Sutton and Lutz, 2018; Vuilleumier, 2005). In particular, phylogenetic relevant stimuli (e.g., threating stimuli), due to their survival value, have been reported to capture attention (Öhman and al., 2001). Nevertheless, Brosch and al. While most of the studies focused on negative stimuli, other work showed that positive phylogenetic relevant stimuli (e.g. baby faces; Brosch and al., 2007) or neutral stimuli associated with a reward (Watson and al., 2019) can automatically capture attention.

Brosch, T., Sander, D., & Scherer, K. R. (2007). That baby caught my eye... Attention capture by infant faces. Emotion, 7(3), 685–689.

attributes.title: Gender moderates racial bias in pain perception
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

dataCollectionDates.value:
Estimated data collection start: February 10, 2020
Estimated data collection end: February 13, 2020

question2a.value:
Independent variable 1: Target race (Black vs. White)
(1)	Within-participant
(2)	Orthogonal

Independent variable 2: Target gender (male vs. female)
(1)	Within-participant
(2)	Orthogonal

question2b.value:
Dependent variable 1: Thresholds for visual perception of painful expressions
(1)	Calculated separately within each race/gender cell. Binary yes/no ratings for each target will be averaged within each race/gender cell, and the resulting averages will be linearly transformed to a scale from 0 to 1 (0 = not in pain, 1 = in pain). This approach was previously used in Mende-Siedlecki, Qu-Lee, Backer, & Van Bavel, 2019.

Dependent variable 2: Treatment recommendations
(1)	Recommendation of 0-20g of a pain-relieving cream in response to an ambiguous pain expression from each target

question3b.value:
a. blatant dehumanization (adapted from Kteily et al., 2015) of black and white Americans [intermixed among other social groups]
b. intergroup contact (adapted from Cloutier et al., 2014)
c. Internal and External Motivation to Respond Without Prejudice (IMS/EMS; Plant and Devine, 1998)
d. gender/race-based expectations of pain sensitivity (adapted from Robinson et al., 2001; Wandner et al., 2012)
e. feeling thermometer ratings of feelings of warmth towards black and white Americans, as well as their overall threat, strength, and status (intermixed with other social groups and traits; proxy for explicit racial bias)
f. target-level social evaluations of masculinity, emotional expressivity, physical & emotional toughness, and height & weight

question10b.value:
Pain rating task
(1)	Participants will complete a modified paradigm from Mende-Siedlecki, Qu-Lee, Backer, & Van Bavel (2019), in which they will see 16 targets (4 black female, 4 black male, 4 white female, 4 white male; created using FaceGen Pro). For each target, there are 11 morph images, ranging from neutral to 100% painful. Each target’s images will be fully contained within their own block of trials. 
(2)	Each block, participants will see a given target’s images increasing in pain from neutral to 100% painful. On each trial, participants will view a stimulus (a morph depicting some level of pain; unlimited time window for response). The participant’s task is simply to indicate with a binary response (Yes or No) whether the morph is in pain or not. Once a participant responds “Yes,” indicating that the given morph they’re seeing on screen looks like it’s in pain, the participant will see a rest slide telling them to click to advance to the next block when they’re ready. (As a result, each participant will see different numbers of stimuli across the pain rating task.)
(3)	Both independent variables (race and gender) are completely within-subjects. Faces are shown in a randomized order within blocks and blocks are shown in a randomized order. 

Treatment recommendation task
(1)	Participants will see 16 targets (4 black female, 4 black male, 4 white female, 4 white male). Each target will be making an ambiguous painful expression. Participants will report how much of a non-addictive pain cream (from 0-20g) they would give to the targets.

Following the task, participants will be asked a series of task-specific questions: an open-ended item asking what they thought the study was about, a multiple-choice item assessing their strategy regarding the pain ratings.

Individual difference measures
(1)	Intergroup contact (short form; adapted from Cloutier et al., 2014)
(2)	EMS/IMS (Plant & Devine, 1998)
(3)	Blatant dehumanization towards various social groups (including black and white Americans; adapted from Kteily et al., 2015)
(4)	A modified version (Wandner, Scipio, Hirsh, Torres, & Robinson, 2012) of the Gender Role Expectations of Pain questionnaire (GREP; Robinson et al., 2001)
(5)	Social evaluations of each target in terms of masculinity, emotional expressivity, physical & emotional toughness, and height & weight
(6)	Feeling thermometer of various social groups (including black and white Americans) in terms of warmth, status, strength, and threat

Debriefing 
(1)	Following the completion of individual difference measures, participants will be debriefed.

question4b.value: Pre-selection measures will be employed on MTurk to screen out non-US participants, participants with a less than 90% acceptance rate on MTurk, and participants in previous tasks from our lab.

question5b.value: 200 White participants will be recruited from Amazon’s Mechanical Turk. (As we will not employ a race/ethnicity-based exclusion criteria on MTurk, additional non-White participants will complete the task as well.)

question6b.value: This sample size will afford us 80% power to detect a small effect size f of .10. (Our prior work demonstrates that the interaction between target race and gender is considerably larger than this, but this sample size will ensure that this final examination of the interaction is definitive.)

question7b.value: Exclusion-related items (see below) will be assessed after the initial data collection, and subsequent batches will be collected as needed to bring the sample to 200.

question8b.value:
Due to an uptick in fraudulent MTurk participation involving non-US participants using virtual private servers (Dennis, Goodson, & Pearson, 2018) to evade standard MTurk location constraints, we will screen out participants attempting to complete our survey from outside the US or using a VPS, via the approach demonstrated by Winter, Burleigh, Kennedy, & Clifford (2019).

Non-differentiation of responses (e.g., the same response on 90% of trials or greater) will result in exclusion from all analyses

For the current hypotheses, only data from White participants will be analyzed. However, data from non-White/non-Black and Black participants may also be analyzed in an exploratory fashion.

question9c.value: With regards to DV1 (Thresholds for visual perception of painful expressions), thresholds will be calculated separately within each race/gender cell. Binary yes/no ratings for each target will be averaged within each race/gender cell, and the resulting averages will be linearly transformed to a scale from 0 to 1 (0 = not in pain, 1 = in pain). (This approach was previously used in Mende-Siedlecki, Qu-Lee, Backer, & Van Bavel, 2019.)

question1a.value:
1.	Overall, we predict a main effect of target race on pain perception: participants will see pain more readily on white faces versus black faces. However, we predict that the main effect of target gender on pain perception will not be statistically significant.

2.	In a subsequent treatment recommendations task, we predict main effects of both target race and target gender: black targets will receive lower treatment recommendations than white targets, and female targets will receive lower treatment than male targets.

3.	Despite differences in the effects of target race as a function of target gender, we predict that racial bias in pain perception will be correlated with racial bias in pain treatment both across gender, and within male targets and female targets separately. Moreover, we predict that perceptual bias will facilitate gaps in treatment above and beyond measures of explicit stereotypes and prejudice.

question2a.value:
1.	We also predict an interaction between target race and target gender on pain perception: the effect of target race will be more pronounced within male targets than within female targets.

2.	Moreover, we once again predict an interaction between target race and target gender on treatment: the effect of target race will be more pronounced within male targets than within female targets.

question3a.value: Our stimulus manipulations (e.g., race – black or white; gender – male or female; painful expressions) are clear and concrete. In particular, our painful expressions have been extensively piloted (Mende-Siedlecki, Qu-Lee, Drain, & Goharzad, under revision), and the race/gender manipulations have been used in four previous experiments. As such, no manipulation check is needed.

question5a.value:
Recent work demonstrates that racial bias in pain care stems, at least in part, from a perceptual source (Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019). Racial bias in pain perception cannot be explained by low-level stimulus features, persists even when identical expressions of pain are rendered on computer-generated targets, and facilitates biases in treatment above and beyond explicit stereotypes and prejudice. Critically, this bias in pain perception arises from disruptions in configural face processing (Exps. 3 & 4, Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019). 

Over two decades of research has documented consistent discrepancies in pain treatment across gender, such that women are prescribed pain medication less often and at lower doses than men with comparable conditions or presentation of symptoms (Breitbart et al., 1996; Calderone, 1990; Chen et al., 2008; Cleeland et al., 1994; Faherty & Grier, 1984; Hoffman & Tarzian, 2001; Leresche, 2011; McDonald & Bridge, 1991; Vallerand & Polomano, 2000). Given our own work suggesting that racial disparities in pain care are supported in part by gaps in visual perception of painful expressions (Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019), it's possible that gender disparities in pain care stem from a similar source.

However, work in social perception demonstrates that gender moderates the effects of target race on perception of emotion, and that typically, such effects are larger within male (versus female) targets. For example, while angry black faces are remembered more accurately than angry white faces (e.g., Ackerman et al., 2006), Krumhuber & Manstead (2011) later demonstrated that this effect held for male targets, but not for female targets. Similarly, while happy expressions are categorized faster on white (versus black) faces (e.g., Hugenberg, 2005), this response latency advantage has been obtained when white male targets are presented in the context of black male targets, but not amongst black female or white female targets (Craig, Mallan, & Lipp, 2012; Lipp, Craig, & Dat, 2015; Craig, Koch, & Lipp, 2017).

Previously, we tested whether target gender shapes the effects of target race on pain perception across four behavioral experiments. Taken together, we observed an interaction between race and gender: racial bias in pain perception was larger in male versus female targets. Moreover, we observed no consistent gender bias in pain perception, but a consistent effect of target gender on treatment: female targets received less pain reliever than male targets. That said, three of these experiments are somewhat underpowered due to an uptick in fraudulent responses on Mechanical Turk. The fourth study was conducted in-lab, and was the only study of the four not to yield a significant interaction between target race and gender. As such, we’re seeking to conduct a well-powered final study in order to reach consensus as to the effects of target race and gender on pain perception and treatment.

question6a.value:
It remains possible that we will observe no interaction between target race and target gender on pain perception thresholds. (Indeed, this was the pattern we observed in the one in-lab version of this task -- where race biased thresholds for seeing pain on black vs. white faces in both male and female targets -- as compared to the three online versions we ran.) This would imply that racial bias in pain perception generalizes across target gender.

Moreover, we do not make strong predictions regarding the individual difference variables, we generally predict that racial bias in pain perception will be positively correlated with blatant dehumanization and EMS, and negatively correlated with increased intergroup contact and IMS. Dehumanization (Fincher & Tetlock, 2016) and increased intergroup contact (Hancock & Rhodes, 2008; Rhodes et al., 2009) have been demonstrated to impede and facilitate (respectively) configural processing of other-race faces. In turn, disruptions in configural processing support racial bias in pain perception (Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019). We also note that across the previous studies we've conducted using this paradigm, biases in masculinity judgments and expressivity judgments specifically were linked to racial bias in pain perception within female targets, and further, that gender stereotypes regarding pain sensitivity (specifically judging females [vs. males] as being more sensitive to pain) were correlated with providing *less* treatment to female targets during the treatment task. We will assess the extent to which these patterns are conserved in the present study.

question1c.value: With regards to Directional Hypothesis #1, we predict a main effect of target race on pain perception; participants will see pain less readily on Black (vs. White) faces overall. However, we also predict no significant main effect of target gender on pain perception; the overall difference between participants’ thresholds for seeing pain on male vs. female faces will not be statistically significant.

question2c.value: These predictions will be assessed in a 2x2 ANOVA assessing the interaction between target race and gender on pain perception.

question1c.value: With regards to Direction Hypothesis #2, in a subsequent treatment recommendations task, we predict a main effect of target race: black targets will receive lower treatment recommendations than white targets. We also predict a main effect of target gender on treatment recommendations: female targets will receive lower treatment recommendations than male targets.

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in a 2x2 ANOVA assessing the effects of target race and gender on pain treatment.

question3c.value:
IV: race (Black vs. White)
IV: gender (male vs. female)
DV: treatment recommendation

question1c.value: With regards to Interaction Hypothesis #2, we predict an interaction between race and gender; racial bias in pain treatment (e.g., lower prescriptions to black versus white targets) will be larger within male (vs. female) targets.

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in a 2x2 ANOVA assessing the effects of target race and gender on pain treatment.

question3c.value:
IVs: race (Black vs. White), gender (male vs. female)
DV: treatment recommendation

question1c.value: With regards to Interaction Hypothesis #1 we predict an interaction between target race and gender on pain perception; racial bias in pain perception (e.g., a tendency to see pain less readily on black targets’ faces) will be larger within male (vs. female) targets.

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in a 2x2 ANOVA assessing the interaction between target race and gender on pain perception.

question3c.value:
IVs: race (Black vs. White), gender (male vs. female)
DV: Thresholds for visual perception of painful expressions

question1c.value: With regards to the Directional Hypothesis #3, racial bias and gender bias in pain perception will be correlated with corresponding biases in treatment in both male and female targets. Moreover, racial bias in pain perception will facilitate bias in treatment within both male and female targets over and above other potential mediators.

question2c.value: These predictions will be assessed a) in separate bivariate correlational analyses and b) in separate within-subjects mediation analyses (Montoya & Hayes, 2017). If the 95% confidence interval bounding a given indirect effect of perceptual bias on treatment outcomes does not include zero, this will be taken as evidence supporting the prediction.

question3c.value:
IVs: Racial bias in pain perception (split by male and female targets)
DVs: Racial bias and gender bias in pain treatment (split by male and female targets)

Third variables: Target level social evaluations, group level social evaluations, intergroup contact, dehumanization, pain sensitivity expectations

question4c.value: Target-level and group-level social evaluations of factors like size, toughness, threat, and status capture factors linked to racial discrimination in the pain care context (e.g., Trawalter et al., 2012; Hoffman et al., 2016), and in general (e.g., Wilson et al., 2017). Increased intergroup contact and blatant dehumanization are both linked to race-based disruptions in visual perception.

Estimated data collection end: February 13, 2020

registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a:
Recent work demonstrates that racial bias in pain care stems, at least in part, from a perceptual source (Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019). Racial bias in pain perception cannot be explained by low-level stimulus features, persists even when identical expressions of pain are rendered on computer-generated targets, and facilitates biases in treatment above and beyond explicit stereotypes and prejudice. Critically, this bias in pain perception arises from disruptions in configural face processing (Exps. 3 & 4, Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019). 

Over two decades of research has documented consistent discrepancies in pain treatment across gender, such that women are prescribed pain medication less often and at lower doses than men with comparable conditions or presentation of symptoms (Breitbart et al., 1996; Calderone, 1990; Chen et al., 2008; Cleeland et al., 1994; Faherty & Grier, 1984; Hoffman & Tarzian, 2001; Leresche, 2011; McDonald & Bridge, 1991; Vallerand & Polomano, 2000). Given our own work suggesting that racial disparities in pain care are supported in part by gaps in visual perception of painful expressions (Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019), it's possible that gender disparities in pain care stem from a similar source.

However, work in social perception demonstrates that gender moderates the effects of target race on perception of emotion, and that typically, such effects are larger within male (versus female) targets. For example, while angry black faces are remembered more accurately than angry white faces (e.g., Ackerman et al., 2006), Krumhuber & Manstead (2011) later demonstrated that this effect held for male targets, but not for female targets. Similarly, while happy expressions are categorized faster on white (versus black) faces (e.g., Hugenberg, 2005), this response latency advantage has been obtained when white male targets are presented in the context of black male targets, but not amongst black female or white female targets (Craig, Mallan, & Lipp, 2012; Lipp, Craig, & Dat, 2015; Craig, Koch, & Lipp, 2017).

Previously, we tested whether target gender shapes the effects of target race on pain perception across four behavioral experiments. Taken together, we observed an interaction between race and gender: racial bias in pain perception was larger in male versus female targets. Moreover, we observed no consistent gender bias in pain perception, but a consistent effect of target gender on treatment: female targets received less pain reliever than male targets. That said, three of these experiments are somewhat underpowered due to an uptick in fraudulent responses on Mechanical Turk. The fourth study was conducted in-lab, and was the only study of the four not to yield a significant interaction between target race and gender. As such, we’re seeking to conduct a well-powered final study in order to reach consensus as to the effects of target race and gender on pain perception and treatment.
registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question6a:
It remains possible that we will observe no interaction between target race and target gender on pain perception thresholds. (Indeed, this was the pattern we observed in the one in-lab version of this task -- where race biased thresholds for seeing pain on black vs. white faces in both male and female targets -- as compared to the three online versions we ran.) This would imply that racial bias in pain perception generalizes across target gender.

Moreover, we do not make strong predictions regarding the individual difference variables, we generally predict that racial bias in pain perception will be positively correlated with blatant dehumanization and EMS, and negatively correlated with increased intergroup contact and IMS. Dehumanization (Fincher & Tetlock, 2016) and increased intergroup contact (Hancock & Rhodes, 2008; Rhodes et al., 2009) have been demonstrated to impede and facilitate (respectively) configural processing of other-race faces. In turn, disruptions in configural processing support racial bias in pain perception (Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019). We also note that across the previous studies we've conducted using this paradigm, biases in masculinity judgments and expressivity judgments specifically were linked to racial bias in pain perception within female targets, and further, that gender stereotypes regarding pain sensitivity (specifically judging females [vs. males] as being more sensitive to pain) were correlated with providing *less* treatment to female targets during the treatment task. We will assess the extent to which these patterns are conserved in the present study.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
Independent variable 1: Target race (Black vs. White)
(1)	Within-participant
(2)	Orthogonal

Independent variable 2: Target gender (male vs. female)
(1)	Within-participant
(2)	Orthogonal
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b:
Dependent variable 1: Thresholds for visual perception of painful expressions
(1)	Calculated separately within each race/gender cell. Binary yes/no ratings for each target will be averaged within each race/gender cell, and the resulting averages will be linearly transformed to a scale from 0 to 1 (0 = not in pain, 1 = in pain). This approach was previously used in Mende-Siedlecki, Qu-Lee, Backer, & Van Bavel, 2019.

Dependent variable 2: Treatment recommendations
(1)	Recommendation of 0-20g of a pain-relieving cream in response to an ambiguous pain expression from each target
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b:
a. blatant dehumanization (adapted from Kteily et al., 2015) of black and white Americans [intermixed among other social groups]
b. intergroup contact (adapted from Cloutier et al., 2014)
c. Internal and External Motivation to Respond Without Prejudice (IMS/EMS; Plant and Devine, 1998)
d. gender/race-based expectations of pain sensitivity (adapted from Robinson et al., 2001; Wandner et al., 2012)
e. feeling thermometer ratings of feelings of warmth towards black and white Americans, as well as their overall threat, strength, and status (intermixed with other social groups and traits; proxy for explicit racial bias)
f. target-level social evaluations of masculinity, emotional expressivity, physical & emotional toughness, and height & weight
registration_responses.recommended-analysis.specify.question9c: With regards to DV1 (Thresholds for visual perception of painful expressions), thresholds will be calculated separately within each race/gender cell. Binary yes/no ratings for each target will be averaged within each race/gender cell, and the resulting averages will be linearly transformed to a scale from 0 to 1 (0 = not in pain, 1 = in pain). (This approach was previously used in Mende-Siedlecki, Qu-Lee, Backer, & Van Bavel, 2019.)
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Pain rating task
(1)	Participants will complete a modified paradigm from Mende-Siedlecki, Qu-Lee, Backer, & Van Bavel (2019), in which they will see 16 targets (4 black female, 4 black male, 4 white female, 4 white male; created using FaceGen Pro). For each target, there are 11 morph images, ranging from neutral to 100% painful. Each target’s images will be fully contained within their own block of trials. 
(2)	Each block, participants will see a given target’s images increasing in pain from neutral to 100% painful. On each trial, participants will view a stimulus (a morph depicting some level of pain; unlimited time window for response). The participant’s task is simply to indicate with a binary response (Yes or No) whether the morph is in pain or not. Once a participant responds “Yes,” indicating that the given morph they’re seeing on screen looks like it’s in pain, the participant will see a rest slide telling them to click to advance to the next block when they’re ready. (As a result, each participant will see different numbers of stimuli across the pain rating task.)
(3)	Both independent variables (race and gender) are completely within-subjects. Faces are shown in a randomized order within blocks and blocks are shown in a randomized order. 

Treatment recommendation task
(1)	Participants will see 16 targets (4 black female, 4 black male, 4 white female, 4 white male). Each target will be making an ambiguous painful expression. Participants will report how much of a non-addictive pain cream (from 0-20g) they would give to the targets.

Following the task, participants will be asked a series of task-specific questions: an open-ended item asking what they thought the study was about, a multiple-choice item assessing their strategy regarding the pain ratings.

Individual difference measures
(1)	Intergroup contact (short form; adapted from Cloutier et al., 2014)
(2)	EMS/IMS (Plant & Devine, 1998)
(3)	Blatant dehumanization towards various social groups (including black and white Americans; adapted from Kteily et al., 2015)
(4)	A modified version (Wandner, Scipio, Hirsh, Torres, & Robinson, 2012) of the Gender Role Expectations of Pain questionnaire (GREP; Robinson et al., 2001)
(5)	Social evaluations of each target in terms of masculinity, emotional expressivity, physical & emotional toughness, and height & weight
(6)	Feeling thermometer of various social groups (including black and white Americans) in terms of warmth, status, strength, and threat

Debriefing 
(1)	Following the completion of individual difference measures, participants will be debriefed.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi: With regards to Directional Hypothesis #1, we predict a main effect of target race on pain perception; participants will see pain less readily on Black (vs. White) faces overall. However, we also predict no significant main effect of target gender on pain perception; the overall difference between participants’ thresholds for seeing pain on male vs. female faces will not be statistically significant.
These predictions will be assessed in a 2x2 ANOVA assessing the interaction between target race and gender on pain perception.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi: With regards to Direction Hypothesis #2, in a subsequent treatment recommendations task, we predict a main effect of target race: black targets will receive lower treatment recommendations than white targets. We also predict a main effect of target gender on treatment recommendations: female targets will receive lower treatment recommendations than male targets.
This prediction will be assessed in a 2x2 ANOVA assessing the effects of target race and gender on pain treatment.

IV: race (Black vs. White)
IV: gender (male vs. female)
DV: treatment recommendation
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Pre-selection measures will be employed on MTurk to screen out non-US participants, participants with a less than 90% acceptance rate on MTurk, and participants in previous tasks from our lab.

200 White participants will be recruited from Amazon’s Mechanical Turk. (As we will not employ a race/ethnicity-based exclusion criteria on MTurk, additional non-White participants will complete the task as well.)

This sample size will afford us 80% power to detect a small effect size f of .10. (Our prior work demonstrates that the interaction between target race and gender is considerably larger than this, but this sample size will ensure that this final examination of the interaction is definitive.)
Exclusion-related items (see below) will be assessed after the initial data collection, and subsequent batches will be collected as needed to bring the sample to 200.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-fourth.fourth.ques: With regards to Interaction Hypothesis #2, we predict an interaction between race and gender; racial bias in pain treatment (e.g., lower prescriptions to black versus white targets) will be larger within male (vs. female) targets.
This prediction will be assessed in a 2x2 ANOVA assessing the effects of target race and gender on pain treatment.

IVs: race (Black vs. White), gender (male vs. female)
DV: treatment recommendation
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-second.second.ques: With regards to Interaction Hypothesis #1 we predict an interaction between target race and gender on pain perception; racial bias in pain perception (e.g., a tendency to see pain less readily on black targets’ faces) will be larger within male (vs. female) targets.
This prediction will be assessed in a 2x2 ANOVA assessing the interaction between target race and gender on pain perception.

IVs: race (Black vs. White), gender (male vs. female)
DV: Thresholds for visual perception of painful expressions
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-further.further.qu: With regards to the Directional Hypothesis #3, racial bias and gender bias in pain perception will be correlated with corresponding biases in treatment in both male and female targets. Moreover, racial bias in pain perception will facilitate bias in treatment within both male and female targets over and above other potential mediators.

These predictions will be assessed a) in separate bivariate correlational analyses and b) in separate within-subjects mediation analyses (Montoya & Hayes, 2017). If the 95% confidence interval bounding a given indirect effect of perceptual bias on treatment outcomes does not include zero, this will be taken as evidence supporting the prediction.

IVs: Racial bias in pain perception (split by male and female targets)
DVs: Racial bias and gender bias in pain treatment (split by male and female targets)

Third variables: Target level social evaluations, group level social evaluations, intergroup contact, dehumanization, pain sensitivity expectations

Target-level and group-level social evaluations of factors like size, toughness, threat, and status capture factors linked to racial discrimination in the pain care context (e.g., Trawalter et al., 2012; Hoffman et al., 2016), and in general (e.g., Wilson et al., 2017). Increased intergroup contact and blatant dehumanization are both linked to race-based disruptions in visual perception.

Due to an uptick in fraudulent MTurk participation involving non-US participants using virtual private servers (Dennis, Goodson, & Pearson, 2018) to evade standard MTurk location constraints, we will screen out participants attempting to complete our survey from outside the US or using a VPS, via the approach demonstrated by Winter, Burleigh, Kennedy, & Clifford (2019).

Non-differentiation of responses (e.g., the same response on 90% of trials or greater) will result in exclusion from all analyses

For the current hypotheses, only data from White participants will be analyzed. However, data from non-White/non-Black and Black participants may also be analyzed in an exploratory fashion.
